text: In Python, is it better to use list comprehensions or for-each loops?
Which of the following is better to use and why?

code:
for k, v in os.environ.items():
       print "%s=%s" % (k, v)

print "\n".join(["%s=%s" % (k, v) 
   for k,v in os.environ.items()])

text: I tend to lead towards the first as more understandable, but that might just be because I'm new to Python and list comprehensions are still somewhat foreign to me.
Is the second way considered more Pythonic?
I'm assuming there's no performance difference, but I may be wrong.
What would be the advantages and disadvantages of these 2 techniques?
